Award.AwardTitle: Direct Observation of Vesicle Dynamics, Collision, and Adhesion

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1704668
PI: Schroeder, Charles

This award will support an experimental and numerical study of the dynamics of vesicles, particles composed of liquid or gas that is surrounded by a membrane, suspended in flow. The vesicles in this project are liquid-filled and are surrounded by a lipid bilayer membrane, which makes them similar to vesicles found in biological systems. They are also similar to synthetic vesicles that are used in a variety of consumer products and foods. The goals of the project are to characterize dynamics of the vesicles in flow, to use the behavior of the vesicles to characterize their mechanical properties, and to study collisions between vesicles and their adhesion. To accomplish these goals, vesicles of known composition will be placed in a microfluidic cell that has multiple fluidic channels arranged to keep the vesicle stationary in the surrounding flow. The deformation of single vesicles and collisions among vesicles will be viewed through a microscope. The results of the project will enable practitioners to design robust and stable vesicles for use in products. The project team will participate in the Illinois iRise program, which works with teachers to develop hands-on experimental labs for K-12 and high school students. The team will also develop hands-on demonstrations for students from underrepresented groups participating in local Boys and Girls Clubs.

The dynamics of single vesicles will be studied in precisely controlled steady and oscillatory extensional flow. Parameters that affect vesicle shapes and the transition from stable to unstable shapes will be examined, including flow rate, membrane bending energy, membrane elasticity and viscosity. A phase diagram for vesicle stability and deformation in extensional flow will be constructed. Results from the project will help resolve discrepancies between experiments and simulations regarding the onset of vesicle shape instabilities such as pearling. The oscillatory flow used in this project will expose vesicles to time-dependent strains, which will expose the effect of unsteadiness on shape instabilities. Collisions and adhesion of freely-suspended vesicles will be characterized. Most prior work has focused on the weak interaction limit, wherein the membrane bending energy plays a dominant role and membrane elasticity is not relevant. However, vesicle membranes deform and stretch upon collision, which has been predicted to give rise to enhanced interactions and unexpected aggregation. The experiments in this project will study collision and adhesion under these conditions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Vesicles are membrane-bound soft containers that play a key role in biology and biomedical applications. Vesicles are often encountered in our everyday lives, ranging from food products to pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, and personal care products. Membrane-bound vesicles are also used in emerging biomedical applications such as delivery vehicles for therapeutics or drugs. Over the last year, our society has witnessed the development of lipid nanoparticle (LNP) formulations for the successful deployment of RNA-based vaccines for COVID-19. Despite their widespread importance, we still lack a fundamental understanding of the stretching and deformation properties of vesicles and lipid membranes in flow. These key knowledge gaps threaten to impede forward progress in the development of new manufacturing processes for vesicles or membrane-based materials. In this NSF award, our work has provided fundamentally new insights into the non-equilibrium properties of membrane-bound materials (e.g. liquid-filled vesicles) in flow. Our work relies on the development of powerful, cutting-edge techniques in automated flow control (known as the Stokes trap) developed by the PI's lab, which has enabled a new quantitative understanding of vesicle dynamics in flow. Broadly, the development of new products and processes with more efficient use of resources, reduced environmental impact, and with advanced properties and functions requires an improved understanding of how the processing conditions, membrane properties, and membrane conformations affect the overall stability of vesicle suspensions during processing.

Intellectual merit: This funded project has provided an improved understanding of membrane mechanical properties, in addition to the stretching and relaxation dynamics of highly deformed vesicles in flow. In Aim 1, our work provided a new understanding of the steady and transient dynamics of vesicle membranes in flow. Our work enabled the direct observation of dynamic deformation and conformational relaxation for vesicles in steady and time-dependent flows as a function of flow strength and membrane deflation (e.g., vesicle 'floppiness'). We developed a highly rigorous statistical toolset based on advanced image analysis and fluorescence microscopy to determine the mechanical properties of vesicle bilayer membrane. In addition, we capitalized on this new understanding of membrane properties to quantify the flow-phase diagram of conformational changes for vesicles in strong flows. In addition, we quantified the large, nonlinear stretching and relaxation dynamics of vesicles in flow. Our work revealed a new relaxation mode for highly deformed vesicles that occurs due to highly stretched and distorted membranes shapes in flow. Remarkably, our results further revealed that the physical properties of lipid membranes (bending modulus) depend on the degree of vesicle deflation. In a collaborative project, we directly observed the wrinkling and buckling shape conformations for vesicles in time-dependent, transient strong flows. In Aim 2, we developed a new technique based on automated flow control for precise manipulation of single or multiple vesicles (or any small particles) in solution. Broadly, this technique (known as the Stokes trap) enables the investigation of the microscale origin of bulk properties such as stress or viscosity, which are key properties in designing and implementing new functional materials. In Aim 3, we made substantial progress towards observing the process of vesicle collision and adhesion for freely suspended vesicles in solution using Stokes trap. Experiments were performed on vesicles in solution without physically constraining or tethering the vesicle membranes. In this way, our work extends far beyond nearly all prior work in membrane deformation that relies on physical attachment of membranes to surfaces or external probes. From a practical perspective, our work provides the potential to unlock new materials or improved processing methods for the manufacturing of functional materials based on vesicles or vesicle membranes.

Broader Impacts: This funded project is highly interdisciplinary, relying on scientific concepts from several diverse fields including rheology, soft materials, microscopy, and fluid dynamics. The nature of this work provides an ideal interdisciplinary environment for training undergraduate and graduate students. In all cases, students are trained to work in a collaborative workspace with science and engineering students from diverse backgrounds. Our ongoing work will be included in several scientific outreach activities, including summer educational camp for high-school girls (Worldwide Youth in Science and Engineering Program, formerly known as the GAMES Camp), an engineering open house at the Beckman Institute for Advanced Science and Technology, and a bilingual scientific outreach program in the local area.
